'''Necrophilia''', also called '''thanatophilia''' and '''necrolagnia''', is the [[human sexuality|sexual]] attraction to [[Cadaver|corpses]]. It is classified as a [[paraphilia]] by the [[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual]] of the [[American Psychiatric Association]]. The word is artificially derived from Ancient Greek: ''[[wikt:Î½ÎµÎºÏÏÏ|Î½ÎµÎºÏÏÏ]]'' (''nekros''; "corpse," or "dead") and ''[[wikt:ÏÎ¹Î»Î¯Î±|ÏÎ¹Î»Î¯Î±]]'' (''philia''; "friendship"). The term appears<ref name="litera">{{ru icon}} [http://www.netslova.ru/gorny/necro.html "ÐÐÐÐ ÐÐ¤ÐÐÐÐ¯ ÐÐÐ Ð¡Ð¢Ð Ð£ÐÐ¢Ð£Ð Ð Ð¡ÐÐÐÐÐÐÐ¯"], 2002.</ref> to have originated from [[Richard Freiherr von Krafft-Ebing|Krafft-Ebing]]'s 1886 work ''[[Psychopathia Sexualis (book)|Psychopathia Sexualis]]''.<ref>Krafft-Ebing, Richard von (1886). ''Psychopathia Sexualis''. English translation: ISBN 1-55970-425-X.</ref>
+
'''Necrophilia''', also called '''thanatophilia''' and '''necrolagnia''', is the [[human sexuality|sexual]] attraction to [[Cadaver|corpses]]. It is classified as a [[paraphilia]] by the [[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual]] of the [[American Psychiatric Association]]. The word is artificially derived from Ancient Greek: ''[[wikt:Î½ÎµÎºÏÏÏ|Î½ÎµÎºÏÏÏ]]'' (''nekros''; "corpse," or "dead") and ''[[wikt:ÏÎ¹Î»Î¯Î±|ÏÎ¹Î»Î¯Î±]]'' (''philia''; "friendship"). The term appears to have originated from [[Richard Freiherr von Krafft-Ebing|Krafft-Ebing]]'s 1886 work ''[[Psychopathia Sexualis (book)|Psychopathia Sexualis]]''.<ref>Krafft-Ebing, Richard von (1886). ''Psychopathia Sexualis''. English translation: ISBN 1-55970-425-X.</ref>
â
<!--Figuratively, the term "necrophilia" describes an inordinate desire to control another person.<ref> *[[Daniel Z. Epstein]] http://ssrn.com/abstract=959534 "Romance is Dead"] 2007. </ref>
 
Thirty-four cases from the whole sample provided self-reports of their motivations: These included the desire to possess an unresisting and unrejecting partner (68%), reunions with a romantic partner (21%), sexual attraction to corpses (15%), comfort or overcoming feelings of isolation (15%), or seeking self-esteem by expressing power over a homicide victim (12%) -->
Thirty-four cases from the whole sample provided self-reports of their motivations: These included the desire to possess an unresisting and unrejecting partner (68%), reunions with a romantic partner (21%), sexual attraction to corpses (15%), comfort or overcoming feelings of isolation (15%), or seeking self-esteem by expressing power over a homicide victim (12%) -->
Line 10: Line 10:
==History==
==History==
â
+
[[Herodotus]] writes in [[Histories (Herodotus)|''The Histories'']] that, to discourage intercourse with a corpse, ancient Egyptians left deceased beautiful women to decay for "three or four days" before giving them to the [[embalmers]].<ref>Herodotus ([[circa|c.]] 440 BC). ''The Histories'', [http://www.gutenberg.org/dirs/etext01/1hofh10.txt Book II], 89:
â
[[Herodotus]] writes<ref>Herodotus ([[circa|c.]] 440 BC). ''The Histories'', [http://www.gutenberg.org/dirs/etext01/1hofh10.txt Book II], 89:
+
:"The wives of men of rank when they die are not given at once to be embalmed, nor such women as are very beautiful or of greater regard than others, but on the third or fourth day after their death (and not before) they are delivered to the embalmers. They do so about this matter in order that the embalmers may not abuse their women, for they say that one of them was taken once doing so to the corpse of a woman lately dead, and his fellow-craftsman gave information."</ref><ref>Brill, Abraham A. (1941). "Necrophilia," ''Journal of Criminal Psychopathology'', 2(4), 433-443.</ref><ref name="klaf"/> This practice originated from the need to discourage the men performing the funerary customs from having sexual interest in their charges.
â
:"The wives of men of rank when they die are not given at once to be embalmed, nor such women as are very beautiful or of greater regard than others, but on the third or fourth day after their death (and not before) they are delivered to the embalmers. They do so about this matter in order that the embalmers may not abuse their women, for they say that one of them was taken once doing so to the corpse of a woman lately dead, and his fellow-craftsman gave information."</ref> in [[Histories (Herodotus)|''The Histories'']] that, to discourage intercourse with a corpse, ancient Egyptians left deceased beautiful women to decay for "three or four days" before giving them to the [[embalmers]].<ref>Brill, Abraham A. (1941). "Necrophilia," ''Journal of Criminal Psychopathology'', 2(4), 433-443.</ref><ref name="klaf"/> This practice originated from the need to discourage the men performing the funerary customs from having sexual interest in their charges.
 
In some societies the practice was enacted owing to a belief that the soul of an unmarried woman would not find peace; among the [[Jingpo|Kachin]] of Myanmar, versions of a marriage ceremony were held to lay a dead virgin to rest, which would involve intercourse with the corpse. Similar practices existed in some pre-modern Central European societies when a woman who was engaged to be married died before the wedding.<ref>Walker, Benjamin. ''Encyclopaedia of Metaphysical Medicine'', Routledge 1978, pp. 191-2. Walker cites Rollo Ahmed, ''The Black Art'', John Long, London, 1936, in support.</ref>
In some societies the practice was enacted owing to a belief that the soul of an unmarried woman would not find peace; among the [[Jingpo|Kachin]] of Myanmar, versions of a marriage ceremony were held to lay a dead virgin to rest, which would involve intercourse with the corpse. Similar practices existed in some pre-modern Central European societies when a woman who was engaged to be married died before the wedding.<ref>Walker, Benjamin. ''Encyclopaedia of Metaphysical Medicine'', Routledge 1978, pp. 191-2. Walker cites Rollo Ahmed, ''The Black Art'', John Long, London, 1936, in support.</ref>

==Classification of Necrophilia==
+
==Classification==
â
Aggrawal<ref name="aggrawal_classification">{{cite journal |author=Aggrawal, Anil. |title=A new classification of necrophilia |journal=J Forensic Leg Med |volume=16 |issue=6 |pages=316-20 |year=2009 |month=August |pmid=19573840 |doi=10.1016/j.jflm.2008.12.023 |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B8CY1-4VGDNXT-2&_user=5081486&_coverDate=08%2F31%2F2009&_rdoc=5&_fmt=high&_orig=browse&_srch=doc-info(%23toc%2340101%232009%23999839993%231262082%23FLA%23display%23Volume)&_cdi=40101&_sort=d&_docanchor=&_ct=22&_acct=C000047720&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=5081486&md5=d9a87333539d30346df1d65ec7a68121}}</ref> has suggested a ten tier classification of necrophilia. The classes suggested by him are
+
Aggrawal has suggested a ten-tier classification of necrophilia:<ref name="aggrawal_classification">{{cite journal |author=Aggrawal, Anil. |title=A new classification of necrophilia |journal=J Forensic Leg Med |volume=16 |issue=6 |pages=316-20 |year=2009 |month=August |pmid=19573840 |doi=10.1016/j.jflm.2008.12.023 |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B8CY1-4VGDNXT-2&_user=5081486&_coverDate=08%2F31%2F2009&_rdoc=5&_fmt=high&_orig=browse&_srch=doc-info(%23toc%2340101%232009%23999839993%231262082%23FLA%23display%23Volume)&_cdi=40101&_sort=d&_docanchor=&_ct=22&_acct=C000047720&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=5081486&md5=d9a87333539d30346df1d65ec7a68121}}</ref>
â

+

â

==Research==
==Research==
Line 55: Line 55:
{{main|Davian behavior}}
{{main|Davian behavior}}
â
Necrophilia is not unknown in animals, with a number of confirmed observations.<ref name="Guardian 2: Electric Boogaloo">{{Cite web|url=http://education.guardian.co.uk/higher/research/improbable/story/0,,1437560,00.html|title=Randy rock doves join party with the dead|accessdate = 2007-06-17|publisher=The Guardian|year=2005}}</ref> [[Kees Moeliker]] allegedly made one of these observations while he was sitting in his office at the [[Natuurmuseum Rotterdam]], when he heard the distinctive thud of a bird hitting the glass facade of the building. Upon inspection, he discovered a drake (male) [[mallard]] lying dead about two meters from the building. Next to the downed bird there was a second [[drake]] mallard standing close by. As Moeliker observed the couple, the living drake picked at the corpse of the dead one for a few minutes and then mounted the corpse and began copulating with it. The act of necrophilia lasted for about 75 minutes, in which time, according to Moeliker, the living drake took two short breaks before resuming with copulating behavior. Moeliker surmised that at the time of the collision with the window the two mallards were engaged in a common pattern in [[duck]] behavior which is called [[Animal sexual behaviour|rape flight]]. "When one died the other one just went for it and didn't get any negative feedback -- well, didn't get any feedback," according to Moeliker.<ref name="Mallard Duck">{{cite journal | author=C.W. Moeliker| title=The first case of homosexual necrophilia in the Anas platyrhynchos (Aves:Anatidae)| journal=Deinsea - Annual of the Natural History Museum Rotterdam| year=2001| volume=8| pages=243â247}}</ref><ref name="MallardDuck">{{Cite web|url=http://education.guardian.co.uk/higher/research/story/0,9865,1432991,00.html|title=Necrophilia among ducks ruffles research feathers|accessdate = 2007-06-17|publisher=Guardian Unlimited|year=2005|author=Donald MacLeod}}</ref> This is the first recorded case of necrophilia in the [[mallard duck]]- though not the only recorded case of [[homosexuality]] within the bird family.<ref name="NYTSqueak">{{cite news |first=Dinitia |last=Smith |url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9506efd9113bf934a35751c0a9629c8b63 |title=Love That Dare Not Squeak Its Name |publisher=New York Times |page=7 |date=[[2004-02-07]]}}</ref>
+
Necrophilia is known to occur in animals, with a number of confirmed observations.<ref name="Guardian 2: Electric Boogaloo">{{Cite web | url = http://education.guardian.co.uk/higher/research/improbable/story/0,,1437560,00.html | title = Randy rock doves join party with the dead | accessdate = 2007-06-17 | work = [[The Guardian]] | year = 2005}}</ref> [[Kees Moeliker]] allegedly made one of these observations while he was sitting in his office at the [[Natuurmuseum Rotterdam]], when he heard the distinctive thud of a bird hitting the glass facade of the building. Upon inspection, he discovered a drake (male) [[mallard]] lying dead about two meters from the building. Next to the downed bird there was a second [[drake]] mallard standing close by. As Moeliker observed the couple, the living drake picked at the corpse of the dead one for a few minutes and then mounted the corpse and began copulating with it. The act of necrophilia lasted for about 75 minutes, in which time, according to Moeliker, the living drake took two short breaks before resuming with copulating behavior. Moeliker surmised that at the time of the collision with the window the two mallards were engaged in a common pattern in [[duck]] behavior which is called "rape flight". "When one died the other one just went for it and didn't get any negative feedback -- well, didn't get any feedback," according to Moeliker.<ref name="Mallard Duck">{{cite journal | author=C.W. Moeliker| title=The first case of homosexual necrophilia in the Anas platyrhynchos (Aves:Anatidae)| journal=Deinsea - Annual of the Natural History Museum Rotterdam| year=2001| volume=8| pages=243â247}}</ref><ref name="MallardDuck">{{Cite web | url=http://education.guardian.co.uk/higher/research/story/0,9865,1432991,00.html | title = Necrophilia among ducks ruffles research feathers|accessdate = 2007-06-17|publisher=Guardian Unlimited|year=2005|author=Donald MacLeod}}</ref> This is the first recorded case of necrophilia in the [[mallard duck]]- though not the only recorded case of [[homosexuality]] within the bird family.<ref name="NYTSqueak">{{cite news |first=Dinitia |last=Smith |url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9506efd9113bf934a35751c0a9629c8b63 |title=Love That Dare Not Squeak Its Name |publisher=New York Times |page=7 |date=[[2004-02-07]]}}</ref>
In the case of a [[praying mantis]], necrophilia could be said to be part of their methods of [[reproduction]]. The larger female will often decapitate or even eat her mate during copulation.<ref name="Feldman">{{Cite web|url=http://www.colostate.edu/Depts/Entomology/courses/en507/papers_1999/feldman.htm|title=The Praying Mantis|accessdate = 2007-06-17|author=Dan Feldman}}</ref> However, given that the sexual activity of a male mantis is controlled by a brain-like [[ganglion]] in his abdomen it may not be appropriate to refer to him as a "corpse", even when he is decapitated.{{fact|date=June 2009}}
In the case of a [[praying mantis]], necrophilia could be said to be part of their methods of [[reproduction]]. The larger female will often decapitate or even eat her mate during copulation.<ref name="Feldman">{{Cite web|url=http://www.colostate.edu/Depts/Entomology/courses/en507/papers_1999/feldman.htm|title=The Praying Mantis|accessdate = 2007-06-17|author=Dan Feldman}}</ref> However, given that the sexual activity of a male mantis is controlled by a brain-like [[ganglion]] in his abdomen it may not be appropriate to refer to him as a "corpse", even when he is decapitated.{{fact|date=June 2009}}
